content: Testcase "a player is on the same line as the ball" is only checked in validator 12. I recommend adding this situation in a test

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good easy problem : learning how to translate a "real world" problem (inasmuch as soccer is a real world ;) into code.

Nice input format, both pleasant to the human eye and easy to parse for the computer.

Although not a fan, I know enough of the rule to understand easily (and surely the improvements following others' comments also help !). The only thing not obvious at first is what happens when you are on the same line, but reading carefully is enough (same line is not "nearer"). Same thing with the "half" : you handled that with the "transgress" verb.

Now to the quibbles :)
- Maybe the case where a player is not offside only because he is in his own half could have had a test where that would be obvious, instead of mingled with other players. Not 100% sure though, it depends how "easy" you intend this "easy" puzzle to be :)
- I would have preferred a closer match test/validator, but since it seems that the coverage (especially of tests) is OK, this is minor indeed.
- The template should mention the two lines that (always !) need to be printed.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I believe this is a valuable contribution to the codingame puzzle repository. The puzzle concerns a relevant real-world problem which motivates the solver. The statement is very precise, unambiguous and coherent. If you're not familiar with the terminology, this will be a bit of a reading exercise, but this disadvantage on its own is not going to deter me from approving this contribution. There are many test cases and they are quite varied. The test names are at the same time very derived but also very original, which is, frankly, an impressive feat. :) 

Well done!

Edit: I believe the situation is more complex than how I wrote it below. I'm investigating test cases now.

I have some code that only considers the second to last opponent as the offside line, not the ball. It only fails for #6: Fernando Redondo, The DM. I believe (things like) this might be a common problem for people that don't follow football. It took me a bit of time to figure out what was causing it, and I had to look at your reference code. I confirmed that was the problem by patching in the ball detection and decision making and seeing all the test cases pass.

The least you should do (imo), is make sure this single failing test case is not a validator, because that would mean it's impossible for puzzlers to figure out what the problem with their code is.
What I recommend you do, is to add some more test cases for this problem, so people can figure out what they're doing wrong a bit easier.

Other than that, I can't find a flaw in this puzzle. Maybe you could consider it a flaw that it's hard for a non-football fan to figure out exactly what to do, but you could just as easily consider this puzzle a challenging reading exercise. Very well done! :)

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very fun puzzle! Lot's of comments below. Great coverage on the test cases. Nice job!

Very nice puzzle! I found the directions plenty clear. Great job on the field layouts, which looks like it takes some time. I was a bit confused by the number of players per team not always being consistent, but I quickly let go of that since it doesn't really matter.

When I finished, I was left with a feeling of maybe not having done enough test cases. There seems to be a significant number of field configurations that could be tested and I honestly couldn't wrap my head around how much testing is enough. If this is something you have thought about, I'd be interested in your opinion.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
I like the originality and the variable names in the solution (Lukaku, Inzaghi...) :D

I don't play football or watch football or understand football, so I'm very confused. There are many terms I don't know the meaning at all.

Goal section
* Offside position
   ‚Ä¢ Please fix the typo: "postion" => "position".
   ‚Ä¢¬†Which team is considered as the opponent team?
   ‚Ä¢ How do I know who is the second last opponent?
   ‚Ä¢ How do I know whether a throw-in happens from the screenshot?
   ‚Ä¢ How do I know whether a corner kick happens from the screenshot?
   ‚Ä¢ Which side is the opponent's half of the pitch?

* VAR data
   ‚Ä¢ Please fix the typo: "privides" => "provides".
   ‚Ä¢ Please fix the typo: "incoded" => "encoded".

Input section
* You may remove all the quotation marks to make the description clearer. In fact, you may just write {{#.aAbBoO}}, the same that you used in Goal section.

Output section
* Please fix the typo: "sanctionned" => "sanctioned".

Thanks.

Thanks for your feedback as always :-).
I corrected the typos, removed the corner kick statement and added more description for the parsing of the screenshot and the rules of offside. I hope it is less confusing now? Here is the main paragraph I added:
- If the ball is represented by lowercase o, then the attacking team is TEAM_A and the opponent team is TEAM_B. if the ball is uppercase O, then it is the other way arround.
- The size of the pitch (screenshot) is width=51 x height=15. The half-way line is therefore at X=51//2=25.
- TEAM_A attacks from right to left. The TEAM_A's half of the pitch is therefore 25 <= X <= 50 and its second-to-last is the player with the 2nd highest X coordinate.
- TEAM_B attacks from left to right. The TEAM_B's half of the pitch is therefore 0 <= X <= 25 and its second-to-last is the player with the 2nd lowest X coordinate.
- If the ball is at the touch line, i.e. the first or the last row (Y = 0 or Y=14), then it is a throw-in.
Thank you!

Thanks for your feedback, really appreciate it !

For the number of players per team, I think they are consistent. The number of occurences of 'a' + 'A' + 'o' is always equal to 11, and same for 'b' + 'B' + 'O' (Remember that the ball position means there is a player who played from there too).

For the test cases, good point ! I can't tell if these 12 cases are exhaustive (I believe not !) but I tried to cover most of the realistic cases that I can think of, and that one can encounter in an actual football game.
Of course, I ignored some advanced offside rules in the statement to avoid confusion, e.g. I assumed that a player always deliberatelly receive the ball from a teammate and never from an opponenent (Either ('o' + 'A') OR ('O' + 'B'), but in real world the ball can come from an opponent player and then no offside is called).

Anyway, there is a lot of scenarios, variants, rules and field configurations to think about for sure :-)
Thank you very much for the approval and all the useful comments below! It helps a lot to rethink the test cases. Glad you enjoyed the puzzle :)

Thanks for your feedback! :)

Are you sure about the second to last opponent? If you consider only the second to last opponent as the offside line, then the #11 Romario fails (and it's a test, not a validator)!

You are right, to avoid confusion I will add a test case and eventually also switch the #6 validator / test.

I agree it's a bit more difficult for non-football folks and that's why I made sure to give plenty explanations of the rules so it's indeed a kind of reading / learning exercise.
Thanks a lot for the approval and the comments below! Greatly appreciated.

Thank you for your comments :) I did take take them into account:
- I added a test "case where a player is not offside only because he is in his own half" (#13)
- I added a paragraph regarding he two lines that ALWAYS need to be printed.
Thanks for your feedback and approval :)

Regarding the two lines, I was thinking about the *template* (stub generator input) :
```
loop 15 read pitchRow:string(100)
>> write Offside Positions
write VAR Decision
```
But surely no harm in pointing it out also in the output description !
Oh I see. Suggestion added.

Strange, maybe there is a bug on CodinGame's side, as the second "write" line of the stub gets translated in Python to `print("write VAR decision")', hence with a spurious "write"... But I'm not sure you can do something about it (except raise the point to CodinGame staff), and it's really minor, so I approved.
I added 1 test (#12) and swapped 1 validator/test pair. What do you get now with your previous code?

Now the 6th test (Sergio Busquets) and both of the 12th tests fail without the ball consideration patch. The rest passes. I'm not sure about the 11th tests. Shouldn't they still pass because you only consider players up to the middle line? Now I look at it again, the wording "The offside rule applies only to players in the opponent's half of the pitch" doesn't really clear that up for me.

PS, I almost lost my code. codingame creates a new url for the ide if you update the test cases (or possibly other parts of the contribution), so when I went to the new url, my code was gone. luckily I could still reopen an old tab to the old url with my code. I have saved it locally now :)

Oh yes test 11 passes if you consider the 2nd to last AND the middle line but neglect the ball position. Tests 6 and 12 prevent such scenario.

For the wording "The offside rule applies only to players in the opponent's half of the pitch", it means that you aboslutely can't be offside if you are positionned in your own camp. Only players who "transgressed" the middle line and attack the other camp might fall in an offside trap :).

I am going to add this last sentence to the statement for more clarity.
Thanks a lot!
Glad I could help!

I saw you misspelled "positioned" as "positionned" in the last sentence you added.
Additionally, you've misspelled "around" as "arround" in "if the ball is uppercase {{O}}, then it is the other way arround."
Thank you very much! Corrections made.
My mistake on number of players. I missed the ball location also being a player. Making that mistake does not impact the solution so I don‚Äôt think it is a big deal.

Att         Def        Act     Half   Throw    Num      VAR		 Factor

Test 1	A	B	2	No	No	    1		OFFSIDE		2nd Player
Val 1	A	B	2	No	No	    2		OFFSIDE		2nd Player

Test 2	A	B	1	No	No	    1		ONSIDE		2nd Player
Val 2	B	A	0	No	No	    4		ONSIDE		2nd Player

Test 3	A	B	2	No	Yes	    None	ONSIDE		2nd Player
Val 3	B	A	2	No	Yes	    None	ONSIDE		2nd Player

Test 4	B	A	2	No	No	    2		OFFSIDE		2nd Player
Val 4	B	A	1	No	No	    2		ONSIDE		2nd Player

Test 5	B	A	1	Yes	No	    0		ONSIDE		Midfield
Val 5	B	A	1	Yes	No	    1		ONSIDE		Midfield

Test 6	B	A	1	No	No	    2		OFFSIDE		Ball
Val 6	B	A	1	No	No	    1		ONSIDE		Ball

I'd like to see two more test case/validator pairs:

1) Midfield determines the offside line and VAR says OFFSIDE.
2) Ball determines the offside line, but opposite results of test/val 6.

I don't mean to be picky, but approving puzzles can sometimes be risky business if something isn't covered and the puzzle has a glitch.
#1 might not make sense since the offside could then be attributed to being behind the 2nd player, right? Sorry, I‚Äôm somewhat familiar with the game, but definitely not a seasoned veteran.
Yes, the number of players doesn't matter. Just wanted to ensure the consistancy with the puzzle statement (the input being a screenshot of all the pitch state at a given time).

Thanks a lot for the effort of analyzing the test cases :)
It made me go back to the original draft notebook, I realised I somehow swapped markers for test 5 (it was supposed to be OFFSIDE, while the validator5 is the ONSIDE case)... I'll correct that. Thanks !

Ok, correction of test 5 done (no duplicate test case now).
Sorry but I can't see the point of this:
"2) Ball determines the offside line, but opposite results of test/val 6."
Seems to me like just creating duplicate cases ! I mean if a code doesn't handle correctly the ball factor then it will fail the test6 or the validator6 (or both). In general, I "hide" the more trickier case by making it a validator, if I add the opposite pair then it's way more clues for debuging in my opinion.

It can be pretty frustrating when all test cases can be passed while a validator still fails. Do you think this is possible with the current test/val 6 makeup?

I could be wrong, and I have no hard and fast rules to back me up on this, but I thought that if you can pass all the test cases and you haven‚Äôt hard coded anything, you should pass all the validators.

Yes you are right about the validators. Sorry I am too tired now to give a definite confirmation or do additional testing, but I will definitely do it later and eventually add tests.
Meanwhile, feel free to edit / create more tests and configs.
Thank you for your excellent feedback üôÇ

So I checked the previous 6 pairs of tests / validators and it was not possible to pass all the tests and yet fail a validator.
In addition, I added more test cases to have even more combinations. Now there are 11 tests and 11 validators, just like a football game :)
Thanks again!
Cool! I'll take a look tomorrow.

I think this was a good exercises. My code from last week did not do so well today. It failed one test case and a completely separate validator. Last week, it was not critical to keep track of y positions on the field. I was only keeping track of x positions and I passed everything. I was also using a set to hold all the players, The failures today were both a result of two critical players sharing x positions on the field. My set filtered one out as a duplicate since I wasn't storing y positions.

Since this is covered in one test case and one validator, I don't see any issues. I like the new test cases and I like what you did with all the test case names!
Very interesting and detailed feedback ! Thanks a lot :-)

Thank you! It's much more clear now!

One new question: What if there are multiple players at the same 2nd highest/lowest X coordinate? Do we consider all of them?

You're welcome!
It doesn't matter if the 2nd highest/lowest X coordinate is duplicated as you only care about its value. (In the actual football, one strategy is that the defenders try to keep aligned as best as they can, relatively on their half field: it's offside trap).
relatively high*
Ah, I got it, only the horizontal distance (difference in x coodinates) matters. Thanks!

Exactly! Then you need to compare it to the ball horizontal position, the half pitch, and the horizontal positions of the players from the other team (the attacking team that has the ball). Let me know if you manage to solve all the cases. Thanks!
I usually don't solve the puzzles until after they're approved üòõ

üòÜ
Thanks for the previous feedback anyway üëç
